channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Endangered plants bulldozed in Topanga State Park
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagun
item.description: Crews for the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power bulldozed hundreds of endangered plants while working on a wildfire prevention project. State authorities are now investigating, as are L.A. officials, in response to a Times inquiry.
item.content:encoded: Crews for the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power bulldozed hundreds of endangered plants while working on a wildfire prevention project. State authorities are now investigating, as are L.A. officials, in response to a Times inquiry.

item.title: L.A. hit with another legal claim in DWP case, with claims of 'wrongful acts and omissions'
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: The DWP ratepayer whose class-action lawsuit over billing errors at the utility culminated in a $67-million settlement has filed a new claim against the city of L.A.
item.content:encoded: The DWP ratepayer whose class-action lawsuit over billing errors at the utility culminated in a $67-million settlement has filed a new claim against the city of L.A.

media:content.media:description: The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power building.

item.title: Pilot died in military jet crash near Death Valley's 'Star Wars Canyon,' Navy confirms
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The military plane went down near an area often referred to as Star Wars Canyon, near the Naval Air Weapons Station China Lake.
item.content:encoded: The military plane went down near an area often referred to as Star Wars Canyon, near the Naval Air Weapons Station China Lake.

media:content.media:description: A photographer captured a photo of the Navy jet that crashed earlier Wednesday.

item.title: California has the most homeless people of any state. But L.A. is still a national model
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: L.A. officials are the subject of criticism for what many residents see as a failure to handle the homeless problem. But across the country, L.A. is considered to be a model for getting people into housing.
item.content:encoded: L.A. officials are the subject of criticism for what many residents see as a failure to handle the homeless problem. But across the country, L.A. is considered to be a model for getting people into housing.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA February 15, 2018: The streets are lines with tents near East 5th Street and South San Pedro Street in the skid row area of Los Angeles, CA February 15, 2018. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times) (**Editors Note*** This photo is to be used for an Op-Ed story on Homelessness. PLEASE DO NOT USE on another story or social before it is published for the intended story. If you have any questions contact photo editor Mary Cooney Mary.Cooney@latimes.com)

item.title: Santa Ana ex-cop is charged in beating of Mexican immigrant
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: A grand jury charged former Santa Ana Police officer Brian Booker for use of unreasonable force during arrest.
item.content:encoded: A grand jury charged former Santa Ana Police officer Brian Booker for use of unreasonable force during arrest.

media:content.media:description: Gavel

item.title: Trump revived the Cadiz water project. Now California has added a new hurdle
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: Newsom signs a law blocking the controversial project from pumping groundwater from the Mojave Desert without approval from the State Lands Commission.
item.content:encoded: Newsom signs a law blocking the controversial project from pumping groundwater from the Mojave Desert without approval from the State Lands Commission.

media:content.media:description: Water from a pilot well at the Cadiz project pours into a spreading basin in the Mojave Desert. If approved, the water project would move underground water 200 miles west to Southern California suburbs.

item.title: Cedars-Sinai division director and UCLA instructor faces felony child porn charges
item.dc:creator: Alexa Díaz
item.description: Guido Germano is charged with distribution of obscene matter and possession of child pornography, the L.A. County district attorney's office says.
item.content:encoded: Guido Germano is charged with distribution of obscene matter and possession of child pornography, the L.A. County district attorney's office says.

item.title: Man armed with gun fatally shot by deputy after Hyde Park traffic stop, authorities say
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: When the L.A. County sheriff's deputy yelled for the passenger to stop, the man pulled out a handgun and fired toward the deputy, authorities said.
item.content:encoded: When the L.A. County sheriff's deputy yelled for the passenger to stop, the man pulled out a handgun and fired toward the deputy, authorities said.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department officials investigate a scene in Hyde Park after a deputy shot and killed a man during a traffic stop early Thursday.

item.title: Hollywood Bowl rehearsals are a soothing morning escape. And they're free
item.dc:creator: Chris Erskine
item.description: The free morning rehearsals of the L.A. Philharmonic at the Hollywood Bowl are one of this city's hidden gems. If you listen closely, you can hear Dudamel singing out the proper phrasing to his musicians.
item.content:encoded: The free morning rehearsals of the L.A. Philharmonic at the Hollywood Bowl are one of this city's hidden gems. If you listen closely, you can hear Dudamel singing out the proper phrasing to his musicians.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA, TUESDAY, JULY 30 2019 - The Budapest Festival Orchestra rehearses in front of a sparse crowd at the Hollywood Bowl. (Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Chinese billionaire used L.A. as base for audacious aluminum scam that cost U.S. $1.8 billion, feds say
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: A 24-count indictment lays out a billionaire's scheme to import Chinese aluminum disguised as pallets to skirt tariffs and engineer bogus sales to inflate his company's revenues.
item.content:encoded: A 24-count indictment lays out a billionaire's scheme to import Chinese aluminum disguised as pallets to skirt tariffs and engineer bogus sales to inflate his company's revenues.

media:content.media:description: The port of Long Beach is the nation's second-busiest. A city audit released Thursday reveals that some commissioners who oversee the Port of Long Beach were improperly reimbursed for some international travel expenses.

item.title: From the Archives: Natalie Wood on fame and fans
item.description: To help promote the 1966 comedy "Penelope," Natalie Wood sat down for an interview with Times writer Kevin Thomas. She talked about fame and fans.
item.content:encoded: To help promote the 1966 comedy "Penelope," Natalie Wood sat down for an interview with Times writer Kevin Thomas. She talked about fame and fans.

media:content.media:description: July, 1966: Actress Natalie Wood plays a kooky kleptomaniac in movie "Penelope."

item.title: Column One: He'd been kept alive with tubes for nearly 17 years. Who is he, and is it possible he's conscious?
item.dc:creator: Joanne Faryon
item.description: Finding out his name turned out to be the easy part. The tough part was navigating the blurred lines that separate consciousness from unconsciousness — and figuring out whether his smile was really a smile.
item.content:encoded: Finding out his name turned out to be the easy part. The tough part was navigating the blurred lines that separate consciousness from unconsciousness — and figuring out whether his smile was really a smile.

media:content.media:description: CORONADO, CALIF. -- WEDNESDAY, JULY 10, 2019: Ignacio, known to the nurses as "Nacho," and was also known as "Sixty-Six Garage," spends his days in the subacute unit at the Villa Coronado Skilled Nursing Facility at Sharp Hospital in Coronado, Calif., on July 10, 2019. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: This California town wants to be a 2nd Amendment 'sanctuary city' for guns and ammo
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: In the coming months, Needles officials say they plan to work with state representatives on legislation that would exempt the city — and possibly other border towns — from rules on purchasing ammunition out of California and reciprocity with other states over concealed weapons permits.
item.content:encoded: In the coming months, Needles officials say they plan to work with state representatives on legislation that would exempt the city — and possibly other border towns — from rules on purchasing ammunition out of California and reciprocity with other states over concealed weapons permits.

media:content.media:description: NEEDLES, CA - JULY 16, 2019 Ñ Needles Councilman Tim Terral, right, and his wife Holly Terral shoot in the desert two miles outside of town. The councilman put forth a resolution to declare the town a sanctuary city for the second amendment as part of a larger effort to loosen gun laws in Needles. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Gilroy grapples with knowing shooter was one of their own
item.dc:creator: Ruben Vives
item.description: Gilroy is beginning the process of moving on after the Garlic Festival shootings.
item.content:encoded: Gilroy is beginning the process of moving on after the Garlic Festival shootings.

media:content.media:description: GILROY, CALIF. - JULY 30: Laura Miller places a stuff bear at a memorial, to those that lost their lives in the mass shooting at the Gilroy Garlic Festival, sits on the roadside, at the intersection of Uvas Parkway and Miller Avenue on Tuesday, July 30, 2019 in Gilroy, Calif. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fresno County man charged in string of three killings
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: A 33-year-old Fresno County man was charged Wednesday with three counts of murder in connection with crimes that authorities say warrant calling him a serial killer.
item.content:encoded: A 33-year-old Fresno County man was charged Wednesday with three counts of murder in connection with crimes that authorities say warrant calling him a serial killer.

media:content.media:description: Buford King, 33, was charged Wednesday with three counts of homicide.

item.title: Ex-postal worker pleads guilty in L.A.-area mail truck thefts
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: A former U.S. Postal Service supervisor has pleaded guilty to helping rob Los Angeles-area mail trucks of nearly $240,000
item.content:encoded: A former U.S. Postal Service supervisor has pleaded guilty to helping rob Los Angeles-area mail trucks of nearly $240,000

item.title: Body of missing McFarland city manager found in Kern River
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: John Wooner, 57, was last seen alive May 14 at Hillcrest Memorial Park, a cemetery in Bakersfield. His body was found in an SUV submerged in the Kern River.
item.content:encoded: John Wooner, 57, was last seen alive May 14 at Hillcrest Memorial Park, a cemetery in Bakersfield. His body was found in an SUV submerged in the Kern River.

media:content.media:description: The silver Dodge Durango that McFarland city manager John Wooner was driving was found in the Kern River this past week.

item.title: Navy fighter jet crash near Death Valley's 'Star Wars Canyon,' seven visitors injured
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: A U.S. Navy F/A-18E jet crashed about 10 a.m. near Naval Air Weapons Station in China Lake, Calif. It is not yet known whether there are casualties.
item.content:encoded: A U.S. Navy F/A-18E jet crashed about 10 a.m. near Naval Air Weapons Station in China Lake, Calif. It is not yet known whether there are casualties.

media:content.media:description: A photographer captured a photo of the Navy jet that crashed earlier Wednesday.

item.title: Jury begins deliberating at Ghost Ship warehouse fire trial
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Derick Almena and Max Harris are charged with involuntary manslaughter in the deaths of 36 people at a December 2016 party at an Oakland warehouse.
item.content:encoded: Derick Almena and Max Harris are charged with involuntary manslaughter in the deaths of 36 people at a December 2016 party at an Oakland warehouse.

media:content.media:description: An artists loft called the Ghost Ship is gutted after a fire that killed 36 people on Dec. 2, 2016.

item.title: Authorities review video that allegedly shows kidnapping suspect rapping about killing and burying a woman
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Authorities are reviewing video appearing to show a man suspected of kidnapping his girlfriend in Monrovia rapping about killing and burying a woman and being sought by police.
item.content:encoded: Authorities are reviewing video appearing to show a man suspected of kidnapping his girlfriend in Monrovia rapping about killing and burying a woman and being sought by police.

item.title: Can a California law requiring Trump to disclose his tax returns survive legal challenges?
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Legal experts weigh in on the new law signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom requiring President Trump and other candidates in the 2020 presidential primary to release their tax returns in order to appear on the ballot.
item.content:encoded: Legal experts weigh in on the new law signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom requiring President Trump and other candidates in the 2020 presidential primary to release their tax returns in order to appear on the ballot.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses a 2016 voter-approved ballot initiative that will require Californians to undergo criminal background checks every time they buy ammunition starting July 1, during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., Tuesday June 25, 2019. At right is Amanda Wilcox, spokeswoman for the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence, who said the checks required by the new law are "the kind of thing that could have prevented the shooting last week" of rookie Sacramento police Officer Tara O'Sullivan. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Gilroy shooter read literature from both left and right, FBI says
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: As the FBI seeks a motive in the Gilroy shooting, they say gunman Santino William Legan read "conflicting literature."
item.content:encoded: As the FBI seeks a motive in the Gilroy shooting, they say gunman Santino William Legan read "conflicting literature."

item.title: Sen. Elizabeth Warren requests investigation of Border Patrol and ICE detention of U.S. citizens
item.dc:creator: Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
item.description: Sen. Elizabeth Warren, a Democratic presidential candidate, wants to know what policies are in place to prevent unlawful mistaken detentions of U.S. citizens.
item.content:encoded: Sen. Elizabeth Warren, a Democratic presidential candidate, wants to know what policies are in place to prevent unlawful mistaken detentions of U.S. citizens.

media:content.media:description: Democratic presidential hopeful former US Senator from Massachusetts Elizabeth Warren delivers her closing statement in the first round of the second Democratic primary debate of the 2020 presidential campaign season hosted by CNN at the Fox Theatre in Detroit, Michigan on July 30, 2019. (Photo by Brendan Smialowski / AFP) / ALTERNATIVE CROPBRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/AFP/Getty Images ** OUTS - ELSENT, FPG, CM - OUTS * NM, PH, VA if sourced by CT, LA or MoD **

item.title: Chinese billionaire faces charges in $1.8-billion scheme to smuggle aluminum through L.A.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: A Chinese billionaire and the company he founded were accused of hatching a scheme to avoid paying $1.8 billion in tariffs by disguising "huge amounts" of aluminum as pallets and smuggling the material into the United States, according to a federal indictment unsealed late Tuesday.
item.content:encoded: A Chinese billionaire and the company he founded were accused of hatching a scheme to avoid paying $1.8 billion in tariffs by disguising "huge amounts" of aluminum as pallets and smuggling the material into the United States, according to a federal indictment unsealed late Tuesday.

media:content.media:description: At dawn, cranes await traffic at the Evergreen Terminal at the Port of Los Angeles. Activity is picking up, shipping officials say.

item.title: Free tickets to see Rams and Chargers practice at SoCal training camps
item.dc:creator: Chris Erskine
item.description: For the Rams and Chargers, public training camp sessions require advance tickets, which are free. For the Cowboys, just show up, but capacity may be limited.
item.content:encoded: For the Rams and Chargers, public training camp sessions require advance tickets, which are free. For the Cowboys, just show up, but capacity may be limited.

media:content.media:description: Camps allow for casual time with players -- and family. Dallas Cowboys tight end Jason Witten, back in the NFL after a brief retirement, greets his daughters, Landry, 6, and Hadley, 4, in Oxnard.

item.title: Clues to Gilroy shooting found in remote Nevada town: Ammo, gas mask, extremist writings
item.dc:creator: David Montero
item.description: Investigators took items from a triplex where Santino William Legan lived including a bulletproof vest, hard drives and a letter from a woman, records show.
item.content:encoded: Investigators took items from a triplex where Santino William Legan lived including a bulletproof vest, hard drives and a letter from a woman, records show.

item.title: 13-year-old girl killed in Gilroy Garlic Festival shooting remembered as a 'true wonder'
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: On Tuesday night, about 100 of Keyla Salazar's friends, classmates, teachers and family members attended a private vigil at her middle school in San Jose to remember the young girl with a sweet smile and kind heart.
item.content:encoded: On Tuesday night, about 100 of Keyla Salazar's friends, classmates, teachers and family members attended a private vigil at her middle school in San Jose to remember the young girl with a sweet smile and kind heart.

item.description: Authorities said two newborn babies have been found abandoned near a dumpster in Fairfield, Calif. One has died.
item.content:encoded: Authorities said two newborn babies have been found abandoned near a dumpster in Fairfield, Calif. One has died.

From left, Alan Bernstein, chair; Linda El-Farra, board secretary; and board members Shawn Kehoe, Les Robbins and David Muir.

item.title: Gilroy Garlic Festival shooting: What we know about the victims
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: Gilroy police said a 6-year-old boy, a 13-year-old girl and a man in his 20s were killed when a gunman opened fire at the Gilroy Garlic Festival on Sunday.
item.content:encoded: Gilroy police said a 6-year-old boy, a 13-year-old girl and a man in his 20s were killed when a gunman opened fire at the Gilroy Garlic Festival on Sunday.

media:content.media:description: Two people stand outside the emergency entrance to St. Louise Regional Hospital on Sunday in Gilroy, Calif. A gunman opened fire at the Gilroy Garlic Festival earlier in the day.

item.title: LAPD will honor slain officer Juan Diaz at Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels

item.content:encoded: Slain LAPD officer Juan Diaz will be honored on Aug. 12 in a public ceremony at the Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels.

media:content.media:description: Chris Martin, center, and Ricardo Camacho visit a memorial to slain LAPD officer Juan Diaz, in front of LAPD headquarters. Camacho's parents were godparents to Diaz.

item.title: L.A. City Council votes to reimpose limits on living in vehicles
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Under the L.A. rules, people cannot spend the night in their cars on residential streets, or live in their vehicles at any time within a block of a park, school, preschool or day care facility.
item.content:encoded: Under the L.A. rules, people cannot spend the night in their cars on residential streets, or live in their vehicles at any time within a block of a park, school, preschool or day care facility.

media:content.media:description: Jeremy Shriver brushes his teeth as he prepares for bed with his daughter Irah, 19 months at a Safe Park in Los Angeles in June. Jeremy fell ill and lost his job and now lives in the car with his expectant wife and daughter.

item.title: Trump's tax returns required under new California election law

item.content:encoded: Trump or any other White House hopeful who refuses to disclose their tax returns can't run in California's primary in 2020 under the law signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom.

item.title: Kidnapping suspect arrested after hours-long standoff with police in downtown L.A.

item.description: A police SWAT team standoff ends in downtown Los Angeles with the arrest of a man suspected of kidnapping his girlfriend.
item.content:encoded: A police SWAT team standoff ends in downtown Los Angeles with the arrest of a man suspected of kidnapping his girlfriend.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 30, 2019 — LAPD SWAT officers take in custody kidnapping suspect, identified as 27-year-old Robert Anthony Camou in downtown Los Angeles. Earlier SWAT officers surrounded a Toyota Prius that authorities believe was used in the possible kidnapping of a woman in Monrovia and located this morning in downtown Los Angeles with the suspect barricaded inside the car. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Disturbing portrait emerges of Gilroy Garlic Festival shooter
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Amid the screams, flying bullets and bloodshed that erupted on a warm summer evening at the Gilroy Garlic Festival on Sunday, someone shouted a pivotal question at the gunman: "Why are you doing this?"
item.content:encoded: Amid the screams, flying bullets and bloodshed that erupted on a warm summer evening at the Gilroy Garlic Festival on Sunday, someone shouted a pivotal question at the gunman: "Why are you doing this?"

media:content.media:description: This screenshot of Santino William Legan's Instagram account shows a selfie of Legan, who opened fire with an "assault-type rifle" on Sunday, July 28, 2019, at the Gilroy Garlic Festival in Gilroy, Calif., killing two children and another man. (Instagram via AP)

item.title: In a blow to the bullet train, California might shift billions to L.A. and Bay Area projects

item.description: A plan is quietly gaining support to truncate California's troubled high-speed rail construction project in the Central Valley and spend some of the remaining billions of dollars in Southern California and the Bay Area.
item.content:encoded: A plan is quietly gaining support to truncate California's troubled high-speed rail construction project in the Central Valley and spend some of the remaining billions of dollars in Southern California and the Bay Area.

item.title: A 19-year-old with a semiautomatic rifle shatters Gilroy's beloved garlic festival, killing 3, including 2 children
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: A 19-year-old armed with an assault-style weapon opens fire at the Gilroy Garlic Festival, killing three people, including two children. The gunman was killed by police.
item.content:encoded: A 19-year-old armed with an assault-style weapon opens fire at the Gilroy Garlic Festival, killing three people, including two children. The gunman was killed by police.

item.title: Gilroy Garlic Festival shooting rampage is awful but not surprising
item.dc:creator: Robin Abcarian
item.description: After the Gilroy Garlic Festival shooting, it's starting to feel like we take our lives in our hands every time we gather in public
item.content:encoded: After the Gilroy Garlic Festival shooting, it's starting to feel like we take our lives in our hands every time we gather in public

media:content.media:description: Gabrielle Sunseri, 16, incoming junior at Gilroy High School. She was a volunteer at the festival Sunday, in a section called "Gourmet Alley" when the gunman began shooting. She ended up spending 20 minutes in a freezer truck, with the freezer on, with about 50 other panicked people.

item.title: At Gilroy Garlic Festival vigils, residents pray for peace
item.dc:creator: Ruben Vives
item.description: Hundreds gathered Monday night in Gilroy to grieve together over the killings Sunday of three people at the city's annual garlic festival.
item.content:encoded: Hundreds gathered Monday night in Gilroy to grieve together over the killings Sunday of three people at the city's annual garlic festival.

media:content.media:description: GILROY, CALIF. - JULY 29: Amber Bruce, 23 of Gilroy, center, places her hand over her heart during the singing of the National Anthem, at a candlelight vigil at Gilroy City Hall on Monday, July 29, 2019 in Gilroy, Calif. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Gilroy Garlic Festival gunman used a rifle banned in California, officials say

item.title: California's biggest oil spill in decades brings more defiance than anger from locals
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagun
item.description: If crude oil spills in California oil country, does anyone care? In the Kern County town of McKittrick, they say it's just the price of doing business. They want everyone to stop fussing over a Chevron well that's leaked a million gallons of oil and water in nearby Cymric oil field.
item.content:encoded: If crude oil spills in California oil country, does anyone care? In the Kern County town of McKittrick, they say it's just the price of doing business. They want everyone to stop fussing over a Chevron well that's leaked a million gallons of oil and water in nearby Cymric oil field.

media:content.media:description: McKITTRICK, CA - JULY 23, 2019 — Sunsets over Cymric oil field in McKittrick. A surface expression vent in the Cymric oil field, near the Kern County town of McKittrick, has released about 800,000 gallons of oil and water. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fossil fuel money flows into council race in Valley area hit by Aliso Canyon methane disaster
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Money from the fossil fuel industry has become a prickly issue in the race for a seat on the Los Angeles City Council representing the northwestern San Fernando Valley.
item.content:encoded: Money from the fossil fuel industry has become a prickly issue in the race for a seat on the Los Angeles City Council representing the northwestern San Fernando Valley.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-JULY 20, 2019: Council candidate John Lee, left, speaks with opponent Loraine Lundquist, right, during a Neighborhood Council Town Hall Meeting on July 20, 2019, in Los Angeles, California. The council candidates are representing Granada Hills North and South, Northridge East and West and Porter Ranch. (Photo By Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Remembering the victims of the Manson murders
item.description: Followers of Charles Manson were tied to the deaths of nine people in the summer of 1969.
item.content:encoded: Followers of Charles Manson were tied to the deaths of nine people in the summer of 1969.

media:content.media:description: The five victims slain the night of Aug. 9, 1969 at the Benedict Canyon Estate of Roman Polanski. From left, Voityck Frykowski, Sharon Tate, Stephen Parent, Jay Sebring, and Abigail Folger. The next night, it happened again. Rosemary and Leno LaBianca, a wealthy couple who lived across town, were stabbed to death in their home.

item.title: Charles Manson's murderous imprint on L.A. endures as other killers have come and gone
item.dc:creator: Maria L. La Ganga
item.description: Fifty years later, the Manson "family" murders remain seared into the collective memory of Los Angeles. The question, which persists to this day, is why?
item.content:encoded: Fifty years later, the Manson "family" murders remain seared into the collective memory of Los Angeles. The question, which persists to this day, is why?

media:content.media:description: Sharon Tate's body is taken from the scene of her murder. Her body was found on a sofa, a rope around her neck; she had been stabbed 16 times in the chest and back.

item.content:encoded: An off-duty Los Angeles Police Department officer was found fatally shot Saturday morning in Lincoln Heights, authorities said.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 27, 2019 — LAPD detectives on scene at 26th. Avenue where an off-duty Los Angeles police officer was killed in a shooting in the Lincoln Heights and the shooter is still at large today. The officer identified as Juan Jose Diaz, was last assigned to the department's Professional Standards Bureau, the Los Angeles Police Department. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Finding a repository for San Onofre plant's nuclear waste is a difficult task
item.description: The San Onofre plant is home to 3.55 million pounds of nuclear waste, and it's not clear where it will go.
item.content:encoded: The San Onofre plant is home to 3.55 million pounds of nuclear waste, and it's not clear where it will go.

media:content.media:description: SAN CLEMENTE, CA-MARCH 25, 2014: The San Onofre nuclear generating station shut down in 2013. A recent paper in the National Academy of Sciences says the country now has a choice to abandon nuclear power altogether or embrace the next generation of smaller, more cost-effective reactors, according to the report. (Photo By Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: MS-13 gang created beachhead at Valley high school, but authorities insisted on secrecy

item.description: MS-13 gang members are suspected of stabbing a student at Panorama High School before luring another student, Brayan Andino, off-campus and killing him. The accused gang members included Panorama High students.
item.content:encoded: MS-13 gang members are suspected of stabbing a student at Panorama High School before luring another student, Brayan Andino, off-campus and killing him. The accused gang members included Panorama High students.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 22, 2019 - Students and parents arrive for summer session at Panorama High School in the San Fernando Valley located at 8015 Van Nuys Blvd, Panorama City on Monday morning July 22, 2019 after learning that suspects in an alleged MS-13 murder were apparently attending Panorama High School. Student Brayan Andino was killed in Dec. 2017. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Essential California Week in Review: A climate deal with automakers
item.dc:creator: Julia Wick
item.description: A look at the top California stories from the past week, including a deal between major automakers and air regulators.
item.content:encoded: A look at the top California stories from the past week, including a deal between major automakers and air regulators.

media:content.media:description: MILL VALLEY, CA - MARCH 03: A customer prepares to pump gasoline into his car at an Arco gas station on March 3, 2015 in Mill Valley, California. U.S. gas prices have surged an average of 39 cents in the past 35 days as a result of the price of crude oil prices increases, scheduled seasonal refinery maintenance beginning and a labor dispute at a Tesoro refinery. It is predicted that the price of gas will continue to rise through March. (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images) ORG XMIT: 540950137

item.title: After that $5-billion fine, Facebook gets dinged again: $1,000 by judge overseeing murder trial
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: A San Francisco judge found Facebook and Twitter in contempt Friday for refusing to turn over postings that might help the defense in a criminal trial. Facebook was fined $5 billion earlier this week by the Federal Trade Commission.
item.content:encoded: A San Francisco judge found Facebook and Twitter in contempt Friday for refusing to turn over postings that might help the defense in a criminal trial. Facebook was fined $5 billion earlier this week by the Federal Trade Commission.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this May 1, 2018, file photo, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg delivers the keynote speech at F8, Facebook's developer conference, in San Jose, Calif. Federal regulators are fining Facebook $5 billion for privacy violations and instituting new oversight and restrictions on its business. But they are only holding Zuckerberg personally responsible in a limited fashion.
